review.title: Belief revision in the propositional closure of a qualitative algebra
review.abstract: Belief revision is an operation that aims at modifying old be-liefs so that they become consistent with new ones. The issue of belief revision has been studied in various formalisms, in particular, in qualitative algebras (QAs) in which the result is a disjunction of belief bases that is not necessarily repre-sentable in a QA. This motivates the study of belief revision in formalisms extending QAs, namely, their propositional clo-sures: in such a closure, the result of belief revision belongs to the formalism. Moreover, this makes it possible to define a contraction operator thanks to the Harper identity. Belief revision in the propositional closure of QAs is studied, an al-gorithm for a family of revision operators is designed, and an open-source implementation is made freely available on the web.

sections.heading: Introduction
sections.text: One way to study this problem from the point of view of the presentation of knowledge is to consider a formalism and to study some of the faith revision operators defined by it: how they are defined and how they can be implemented. In particular, it is quite easy to redefine a revision operator on the basis of qualitative algebra (QA, like the Allen algebra) by reusing the work of (Condotta et al. 2010) on the related problem of faith fusion. The result of such a faith revision is a set of faith foundations that must be interpreted disjunctively and that are not necessarily depicted as a single basis of faith: QAs do not come under disjunction.This gives an initial motivation for the study of faith revision in the foreseeable conclusion of a QA.

sections.heading: Belief change
sections.text: Belief in a change of faith is an operation of faith change (after the names of the authors of Alchourrón, Gärdenfors and Makinson 1985), but the resulting series of beliefs is noted by the agent and depends on the choice of a revision operator. In (Alchourrón, Gärdenfors and Makinson 1985) the principle of minimal change is formulated as follows: "The principle of minimal change is minimally changed, so that the linkage of the two beliefs is consistent, and the result of the revision is this constellation. Hence, there is more than one possible operator, since the definition of the change of faith depends on how" is measured. "More precisely, the minimal principle of change has been formalized by a series of postulates known as the AGM postulates (after the names of the authors of Alchourrón, Gärdenfors and Makinson).

sections.heading: Implementation: the REVISOR/PCQA engine
sections.text: REVISOR is a collection of several revision motors that are open source and freely available. [1] REVISOR / QA is a collection of several revision motors that are included in the WeiWeiWeiWeiWeiWeiWeiWeiWeide Weil directives. [2] REVISOR / QA is a compilation of three QAs: the Allen algebra, INDU - an extension of the Allen algebra taking into account the relationships between the intervals Morgan Morgan Morgan Morgan Morgan Morgan Morgan Morgan Morgan Morgan Morgan Morgan Morgan Morgan Morgan Morgan Morgan Morgan Morgan - and RCC8 - a QA for displaying topological relationships between regions of space (Randell, Cui and Cohn 1992). [3] In addition, it is easy to use another qualitative algebra by having some tables (composition table, inverse relation table and table of values). [4] The machine is written in Perl, but can be used through a Java library.

sections.heading: Conclusion
sections.text: This work is motivated by the fact that it provides a revision operation, the result of which can be represented in formalism, by the fact that some practical examples are easily represented in L'QA, while they are quite difficult to represent in LQA, and by the fact that it is possible to define a contraction operator thanks to the Harper identity (which requires disjunction and negation).The pre-processing of the algorithm consists in bringing the formulas into a disjunctive normal form, without negation. Then, proposal 3, which reduces a revision of disjunctions to a disjunction of the cheapest revisions, is applied. REVISOR / PCQA is an implementation of this revision operator for the Allen algebra, INDU and RCC8.A first direction of research following a disjunction of the cheapest revisions.
